title: Romans Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Romans chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Romans Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Romans Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:1, to whom should every soul be subject?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:1 instructs that every soul be subject unto the higher powers, indicating submission to governing authorities.

questions.question: What does Romans 13:2 say will happen to those who resist the power?
options: They shall receive to themselves damnation
questions.correctAnswer: They shall receive to themselves damnation
questions.explanation: Romans 13:2 states that those who resist the power resist the ordinance of God and will receive damnation.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:3, rulers are not a terror to whom?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:3 clarifies that rulers are not a terror to good works but to evil.

questions.question: What does Romans 13:4 say the ruler bears, which is not in vain?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:4 mentions that the ruler bears the sword as a minister of God to execute wrath on evil doers.

questions.question: Romans 13:5 instructs believers to be subject for wrath and also for what other reason?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:5 says to be subject not only for wrath but also for conscience sake.

questions.question: Why should believers pay tribute according to Romans 13:6?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:6 explains tribute is paid because rulers are God's ministers attending to this very thing.

questions.question: Romans 13:7 instructs to render to all their dues. Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a due?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:7 lists tribute, custom, fear, and honour as dues but does not mention gifts.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:8, what is the only debt one should owe?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:8 states to owe no man anything but to love one another, fulfilling the law.

questions.question: Which commandment does Romans 13:9 say is briefly comprehended in loving your neighbor as yourself?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:9 lists commandments including 'Thou shalt not commit adultery' as part of the law fulfilled by loving your neighbor.

questions.question: What does Romans 13:10 say love worketh?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:10 says love worketh no ill to his neighbour, fulfilling the law.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 13:11 says it is now high time to awake out of sleep because our salvation is nearer than when we believed.
questions.explanation: Romans 13:11 states it is high time to awake out of sleep as salvation is nearer, confirming the truth of the statement.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 13:12 encourages believers to put on the works of darkness.
questions.explanation: Romans 13:12 instructs to cast off works of darkness and put on the armour of light, so the statement is false.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 13:13 advises walking honestly as in the day, avoiding rioting and drunkenness.
questions.explanation: Romans 13:13 tells believers to walk honestly, not in rioting and drunkenness, confirming the statement as true.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Romans 13:14: 'But put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make not provision for the ______, to fulfil the lusts thereof.'
questions.explanation: Romans 13:14 instructs to not make provision for the flesh to fulfil lusts, so 'flesh' is the correct word.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:4, what role does the minister of God have toward those who do evil?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:4 describes the ruler as a minister of God acting as a revenger to execute wrath on evildoers.

medium.title: Romans Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Romans Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Romans 13 teach us about the Christian attitude toward governing authorities?
options: We should resist them if we disagree
We should be subject to higher powers because they are ordained by God
We should only obey when convenient
questions.correctAnswer: We should be subject to higher powers because they are ordained by God
questions.explanation: Romans 13:1 explains that all authority is established by God and believers should be subject to these authorities. This is supported by verse 2, which warns against resisting the power as it is resisting God's ordinance.

questions.question: What reason does Romans 13 give for why rulers punish evildoers?
options: Because they are ministers of God to execute wrath on evildoers
Because they want to control people
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are ministers of God to execute wrath on evildoers
questions.explanation: Romans 13:4 states that rulers bear the sword as ministers of God to punish those who do evil, showing that their role is to promote good and restrain evil.

questions.question: According to Romans 13, why should Christians pay taxes and give respect to governing authorities?
options: Because they can punish us if we don't
Because they are God's ministers, attending continually to governing
Because it is a social contract
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are God's ministers, attending continually to governing
questions.explanation: Romans 13:6-7 teaches that paying taxes and giving respect is due because governing authorities serve as ministers of God, and thus deserve honor and fear as part of God's order.

questions.question: What debt should Christians never owe according to Romans 13?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:8 instructs believers to owe nothing except love to one another, because love fulfills the law, linking love as the primary obligation Christians have toward others.

questions.question: How does Romans 13 summarize the commandments in relation to love?
options: Love your neighbor as yourself fulfills all commandments
questions.correctAnswer: Love your neighbor as yourself fulfills all commandments
questions.explanation: Romans 13:9-10 shows that the law’s commandments are summarized by loving one’s neighbor, and that love works no harm to a neighbor, fulfilling the law.

questions.question: What practical advice does Romans 13 give for Christian living as the time of salvation approaches?
options: Continue in sinful habits until later
Awake from spiritual sleep and put on the armor of light
questions.correctAnswer: Awake from spiritual sleep and put on the armor of light
questions.explanation: Romans 13:11-12 urges believers to recognize the urgency of salvation’s nearness by casting off works of darkness and embracing the armor of light for holy living.

questions.question: Which behaviors are Christians instructed to avoid in Romans 13 when walking honestly?
options: Riot and drunkenness, chambering and wantonness, strife and envying
questions.correctAnswer: Riot and drunkenness, chambering and wantonness, strife and envying
questions.explanation: Romans 13:13 lists specific sinful behaviors such as rioting, drunkenness, immoral sexual activity, strife, and envy that believers should avoid to live honestly as in the day.

questions.question: What does Romans 13 instruct Christians to "put on" to overcome fleshly lusts?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:14 commands believers to put on the Lord Jesus Christ and not make provision for the flesh to fulfill its lusts, highlighting Christ as the believer's protection against sin.

questions.question: How does Romans 13 describe the role of rulers regarding good works?
options: Rulers are a terror to good works
Rulers are not a terror to good works
questions.correctAnswer: Rulers are not a terror to good works
questions.explanation: Romans 13:3 explains that rulers do not threaten those who do good but punish evil, encouraging believers to do good without fear of authority.

questions.question: True or False: According to Romans 13, resisting governing authorities is equivalent to resisting God's ordinance.
questions.explanation: Romans 13:2 states that whoever resists authority resists what God has appointed, making resistance against governing powers resistance against God's ordinance.

questions.question: True or False: Christians can owe debts to others as long as it is not love, according to Romans 13.
questions.explanation: Romans 13:8 teaches that believers owe nothing to anyone except love, emphasizing that love is the only perpetual debt Christians should maintain.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Let us walk honestly, as in the day; not in _____ and drunkenness, not in chambering and wantonness..."
questions.explanation: Romans 13:13 encourages believers to walk honestly, avoiding rioting and drunkenness, showing a lifestyle contrary to works of darkness.

questions.question: Based on Romans 13, how should believers respond to the authority of rulers who punish wrongdoing?
options: With fear and submission, because rulers bear the sword as God's ministers
questions.correctAnswer: With fear and submission, because rulers bear the sword as God's ministers
questions.explanation: Romans 13:4-5 explains rulers are ministers of God to execute wrath on evildoers, and believers should be subject not only to avoid wrath but also for conscience’s sake.

questions.question: What does Romans 13 say is the result of loving one another?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:8-10 teach that love is the fulfillment of the law because it works no harm to a neighbor and summarizes the commandments.

questions.question: How does Romans 13 instruct Christians to live in the light of salvation being near?
options: By casting off works of darkness and putting on the armor of light
questions.correctAnswer: By casting off works of darkness and putting on the armor of light
questions.explanation: Romans 13:11-12 urges believers to awaken from spiritual sleep, cast off darkness, and live as children of light because salvation is nearer than before.

hard.title: Romans Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Romans Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:1, what is the origin of all governing powers?
options: They are established by human wisdom
questions.explanation: Romans 13:1 states that 'there is no power but of God: the powers that be are ordained of God,' indicating divine origin of governing authorities.

questions.question: Romans 13:2 warns about resisting authority. What consequence is promised for those who resist?
options: They shall receive to themselves damnation
They shall be honored by the people
They shall be rewarded in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: They shall receive to themselves damnation
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly says those who resist the power resist the ordinance of God and will bring judgment upon themselves.

questions.question: In Romans 13:3, what is the role of rulers with respect to those who do good?
options: They are not a terror to good works
questions.correctAnswer: They are not a terror to good works
questions.explanation: The verse states rulers are not a terror to those who do good, implying their role is to protect and encourage righteousness.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Romans 13:4 to describe the ruler's authority to punish evildoers?
questions.explanation: The passage says the ruler 'beareth not the sword in vain,' symbolizing authority to execute justice and wrath on evildoers.

questions.question: Romans 13:5 says submission to authorities is necessary not only because of wrath but also because of what?
questions.explanation: The verse emphasizes that submission is required not only to avoid wrath but also for conscience's sake, indicating a moral obligation.

questions.question: Why does Paul mention paying tribute in Romans 13:6?
options: Because it was a Jewish tradition
Because it ensures peace with neighbors
questions.explanation: The verse explains tribute is paid since rulers serve as God's ministers, attending continually to governing duties.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Romans 13:7: 'Render therefore to all their dues: tribute to whom tribute is due; custom to whom custom; fear to whom fear; ______ to whom honour.'
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly instructs to render 'honour to whom honour' is due, reflecting respect for authority and social order.

questions.question: Romans 13:8 states that one should owe no man anything except what?
questions.explanation: The verse clearly states that the only debt one should owe is love, fulfilling the law through mutual affection.

questions.question: Which commandments are summarized as being fulfilled by loving one's neighbor, according to Romans 13:9?
options: Thou shalt not commit adultery, kill, steal, bear false witness, covet
Thou shalt keep the Sabbath holy
Thou shalt not eat unclean animals
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt not commit adultery, kill, steal, bear false witness, covet
questions.explanation: Romans 13:9 lists these commandments and says all others are briefly comprehended in loving one's neighbor as oneself.

questions.question: Romans 13:10 states that love does what to one's neighbor?
questions.explanation: The verse explains love causes no harm to the neighbor and thus fulfills the law perfectly.

questions.question: In Romans 13:11, what does Paul say about the time and our salvation?
options: Salvation is nearer now than when we first believed
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation is nearer now than when we first believed
questions.explanation: Paul exhorts believers to wake from spiritual sleep because the time of salvation is approaching.

questions.question: Romans 13:12 uses the imagery of night and day. What is the instruction given using this imagery?
options: Cast off works of darkness and put on the armour of light
Embrace the darkness as a time for rest
questions.correctAnswer: Cast off works of darkness and put on the armour of light
questions.explanation: The verse poetically urges believers to reject evil deeds (darkness) and embrace righteousness (light).

questions.question: According to Romans 13:13, which of the following is NOT one of the behaviors believers are instructed to avoid?
questions.explanation: The verse lists rioting, drunkenness, chambering, wantonness, strife, and envying as behaviors to avoid; prayer is not mentioned as negative.

questions.question: What is the final exhortation in Romans 13:14 about how believers should live?
options: Put on the Lord Jesus Christ and make no provision for the flesh
Live according to the law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Put on the Lord Jesus Christ and make no provision for the flesh
questions.explanation: Paul urges believers to clothe themselves with Christ and resist fleshly desires, pointing to spiritual transformation.

questions.question: True or False: Romans 13 teaches that submission to governing authorities is only necessary to avoid punishment, not for moral reasons.
questions.explanation: Romans 13:5 clearly states submission is required not only for wrath but also for conscience sake, indicating a moral obligation.

theological.title: Romans Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Romans Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:1, what is the source of all authority and power?
options: Power is derived from popular consent
questions.explanation: Romans 13:1 states that there is no power but of God and that the powers that be are ordained of God, indicating divine sovereignty over all authorities. This is consistent with Daniel 2:21, Proverbs 21:1, and Acts 17:26, which affirm God's control over kings and rulers.

questions.question: What consequence does Romans 13:2 describe for those who resist governing authorities?
options: They shall receive to themselves damnation
They will be rewarded in heaven
questions.correctAnswer: They shall receive to themselves damnation
questions.explanation: Romans 13:2 warns that resisting authority is resisting God's ordinance and that such resistance brings judgment or damnation. This aligns with passages like 1 Peter 2:13-14 and Proverbs 24:21 that encourage submission to authorities ordained by God.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:3, rulers are intended to be a terror to whom?
options: To those who do good works
questions.explanation: Romans 13:3 clarifies that rulers are not a terror to good works but to evil, indicating their role as enforcers of justice. This concept is supported by Proverbs 29:2 and Exodus 22:28, which affirm that rulers punish evildoers and uphold righteousness.

questions.question: What is the role of the governing authority described in Romans 13:4?
options: To bear the sword as a minister of God to execute wrath on evildoers
questions.correctAnswer: To bear the sword as a minister of God to execute wrath on evildoers
questions.explanation: Romans 13:4 teaches that rulers bear the sword as God's ministers to execute wrath on evil doers, showing that government serves as God's agent for justice. This aligns with Old Testament portrayals of God's justice such as in Romans 12:19 and Psalm 9:7-8.

questions.question: Why does Romans 13:5 say believers must be subject to authorities?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:5 indicates that submission to authorities is necessary not only to avoid punishment but also for the sake of a good conscience. This principle is echoed in 1 Peter 2:17 and Titus 3:1, emphasizing obedience as a moral and spiritual duty.

questions.question: What justification does Romans 13:6 provide for paying taxes and tribute?
options: Because rulers are God’s ministers attending continually to this
questions.correctAnswer: Because rulers are God’s ministers attending continually to this
questions.explanation: Romans 13:6 explains that taxes are paid because governments are God's ministers who devote themselves to governing. This is in harmony with Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 22:21 and 1 Timothy 2:1-2 about honoring governing authorities through tribute.

questions.question: According to Romans 13:7, what should be rendered to all people?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:7 instructs believers to render to all their dues: tribute, custom, fear, and honor as appropriate. This reflects the biblical ethic of justice and respect found in Exodus 22:28 and 1 Peter 2:17.

questions.question: What does Romans 13:8 command believers to owe to no one?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:8 states that believers owe no one anything except to love one another, for love fulfills the law. This is consistent with Jesus' summary of the law in Matthew 22:39 and 1 John 4:7.

questions.question: Which commandments does Romans 13:9 summarize as being fulfilled by loving one’s neighbor?
options: Thou shalt not commit adultery, kill, steal, bear false witness, nor covet
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt not commit adultery, kill, steal, bear false witness, nor covet
questions.explanation: Romans 13:9 lists several commandments and states that if there be any other, they are summed up in loving one’s neighbor, echoing Leviticus 19:18 and Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 22:37-40.

questions.question: What is the essence of the law according to Romans 13:10?
options: Love works no ill to a neighbor
questions.correctAnswer: Love works no ill to a neighbor
questions.explanation: Romans 13:10 teaches that love does no harm to a neighbor and is the fulfilling of the law, aligning with Jesus’ commandment in John 13:34 and Paul’s teaching in Galatians 5:14.

questions.question: What does Romans 13:11 urge believers to do in light of salvation’s nearness?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:11 calls believers to awake from spiritual sleep because salvation is nearer than when they first believed, which corresponds with 1 Thessalonians 5:6 and Ephesians 5:14 about watchfulness and readiness.

questions.question: How does Romans 13:12 describe the present time spiritually?
options: The night is far spent, the day is at hand
questions.correctAnswer: The night is far spent, the day is at hand
questions.explanation: Romans 13:12 uses the metaphor of night ending and day approaching to illustrate the urgency for believers to cast off darkness and put on the armor of light, consistent with Isaiah 60:1-2 and 1 Thessalonians 5:5.

questions.question: Which behaviors are believers instructed to avoid in Romans 13:13?
options: Riotings, drunkenness, chambering, wantonness, strife, and envying
questions.correctAnswer: Riotings, drunkenness, chambering, wantonness, strife, and envying
questions.explanation: Romans 13:13 commands believers to walk honestly and avoid sinful behaviors such as rioting, drunkenness, and strife, paralleling Galatians 5:19-21 and Ephesians 5:18.

questions.question: What does Romans 13:14 instruct believers to put on?
questions.explanation: Romans 13:14 exhorts believers to put on the Lord Jesus Christ and not to make provision for the flesh to fulfill its lusts, consistent with Galatians 3:27 and Colossians 3:12.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of rulers bearing the sword as described in Romans 13:4?
options: It symbolizes God’s delegated authority to execute justice
It is a metaphor for spiritual warfare only
It indicates rulers are above God’s law
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God’s delegated authority to execute justice
questions.explanation: Romans 13:4 portrays rulers bearing the sword as ministers of God to execute wrath on evildoers, indicating divine delegation of authority for justice. This is supported by Exodus 21:14, Proverbs 20:8, and Matthew 26:52.
